items.content:
ğŸš€ Frontend Focus

#â€‹612 â€” October 4, 2023 | Read on the web

The Ultimate Low-Quality Image Placeholder Technique â€” Harry notes the importance in offering a reasonably pleasant experience for users who find themselves waiting for images to load, explaining how Low-Quality Image Placeholders (LQIP) are one such possible answer. The problem however is they donâ€™t particularly play nice with Core Web Vitals and Largest Contentful Paint (LCP). This post goes into any nuances to be aware of, along with how best to implement aÂ solution.

Harry Roberts

How Photoshop is Now on the Web â€” Getting Photoshop onto the Web (where it has been for a little while now â€“ we first covered Photoshop's journey to the Web in 2021) was the result of both a lot of collaboration and a myriad of modern browser technologies (WebAssembly, Web Components + Lit, Service Workers & more) that Addy covers in thisÂ post.

Addy Osmani

And itâ€™s our people who make us remarkable. Our success is your success. Letâ€™s celebrate together. LearnÂ more.

Chrome for Developers

We can turn to visual regression testing. SÃ©bastien, known for his work on Docusaurus, shares a workflow based on GitHub Actions, Playwright, and Argos that's suitable for thisÂ task.

FranÃ§ois Beaufort

FranÃ§ois Beaufort also shares what's new in WebGPU for Chrome 118.

Using The Intl Segmenter API â€” Kilian shared on Twitter that he lost some time â€œtrying to detect words in non-western language stringsâ€ but then learnt about the Intl.segmenter browser API. It has a ton of functionality for editing and formatting of text and numbers. This post shows us how to useÂ it.

Kilian Valkhof

Animating Multi-Page Navigations with Browser View Transitions and Astro â€” A beginner-friendly guide, with demos and code, that walks you through the use of the Browser View Transitions API paired with Astro for a smoother navigationÂ experience.

Igor Penaque

Misconceptions Can Kill Accessibility Momentum â€” Reflecting on accessibility misconceptions and how new standards and technologies can inadvertently add toÂ them.

Eric Eggert

Making a Website is for Everyone â€” â€œThe webâ€™s low barrier to entry led me to a career that has been a boon for my life. I hope it can do the same forÂ others.â€

Jim Nielsen

Jeremy Keith

The Angular Renaissance: Why Frontend Devs Should Revisit It

Viselect: Let Users Visually Select DOM Elements â€” If youâ€™ve got a variety of elements and you want users to be able to select them in groups, individually, or even in multiple groups, this lets you offer that functionality easily. Can be used in a vanilla fashion or with integrations for React orÂ Vue.js.

Simon Reinisch

Critical 6.0: Extracts and Inlines Critical Path CSS from HTML â€” A Node powered tool for when you want to optimize a pageâ€™s rendering to the max by inlining above-the-foldÂ CSS.

Addy Osmani

Add Figma Like Collaborative Features in a Few Lines of Code â€” Create collaborative features, from live cursors to avatar stacks with Spaces, our in-app collaborationÂ SDK.

Ably sponsor

blog-cells: Add Runnable, Interactive Code Snippets onÂ Pages â€” Like embedding a JSFiddle or Codepen, but these are a cleaner and minimal solution that work well in tutorials and in SSGs like Jekyll or Hugo. Try some examplesÂ here.

Varun Ramesh

MiniSim: A Native Mac Menubar App for Launching iOS and Android Emulators â€” Itâ€™s open source, includes various configuration settings for a handy mobile testingÂ solution.

Oskar KwaÅ›niewski

Sprite Your SVGs: Paste SVG Code to Generate an OptimizedÂ Sprite â€” CSS sprites arenâ€™t so much of a thing nowadays, but if you have a use case for an SVG sprite, this helps with the codeÂ generation.

JosÃ© Donato

Atrament.js: A Library for Smooth Drawing on HTML Canvas â€” Demo.

items.title: What do you think about HTML in 2023?
items.content:
ğŸš€ Frontend Focus

#â€‹611 â€” September 27, 2023 | Read on the web

Take the State of HTML 2023 Survey (and Change theÂ Web) â€” A new survey from the folks behind State of JavaScript and State of CSS. This is a natural companion to the other two surveys and should result in a more complete overview of the web platform as a whole. We encourage everyone to fill it out as answers submitted by October 1 will be used to inform this year's Interop 2024 proposals. Lea Verou outlines how this survey came to be and what you need to know. We'll share the results too, in dueÂ course.

Devographics

Cloudflare Fonts: Enhancing Web Font Privacy and Speed â€” A new one-click service coming to Cloudflare users that means sites using Google Fonts will be able to load the fonts from their own domain rather than fromÂ Google and reduce the number of round trips from eight toÂ one.

Bullock and Woodhead (Cloudflare)

CSS Foundations with Emma Bostian â€” This extensive video course will help you nail the CSS essentials. You'll learn core terminology, practical skills (such as Flexbox and Grid), and gain hands-on experience â€” all of which will equip you with the fundamentals required for creating professional responsiveÂ sites.

Frontend Masters sponsor

The Path to Awesome CSS Easing with linear() â€” The new CSS linear() easing function is on the horizon, expanding what we can do when it comes to creating more natural-feeling animations and transitions. This post looks at what the current state of CSS easing is and demonstrates what we can expect from linear() once itÂ lands.

Jhey Tompkins

Why HTTP/3 is Eating the World â€” What problems HTTP/3 solves, how it performs, why itâ€™s seen such swift adoption, and what limitations it's still working toÂ overcome.

Robin Marx

âš¡ï¸ IN BRIEF

  • Todayâ€™s Google Doodle celebrates 25 years of the search giant.

  • Firefox 118 is out now and includes automated translation of web content. The general release notes are here, with the developer information here.

  • â–¶ï¸ A video outlining what's new in version 1.38 of web testing and automation framework Playwright.

  • Ben Hawkes goes deep into a significant WebP related security vulnerability that could allow out of bounds memory writes via a specially crafted HTML page. More discussionÂ here.

ğŸ“™ Tutorials, Articles & Opinion

The Design System Ecosystem â€” This post goes deep into the weeds on a â€˜layer-cake approachâ€™ to creating robust, mature design systems. Of course, the advice isnâ€™t one size fits all, but thereâ€™s plenty of good takeawaysÂ here.

Brad Frost

Responsive Type Scales with Composable CSS Utilities â€” With the help of calc(), clamp() and CSS vars, we can create composable, responsive, and fluid type scales that smoothly adapts to viewport and containerÂ widths.

Five frontend recommendations from Ahmad Shadeed, design engineer, writer at ishadeed.com, and author of Debugging CSS.

    This is a CSS linter that helps me avoid CSS mistakes upfront.

    I like this a lot because it gives us the power of Tailwind, but with pure CSS variables.

    This is my most used tool while building stuff, it's opened by default.

    I don't think twice when I need to try something in the browser. I type pen.new and go fromÂ there.

nue
